Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Innovative Platform Technology for Rapid Three Dimensional Micro Fabrication
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will reduce health costs and increase accessibility to diagnostics by reducing the cost of manufacture, and increasing manufacturing volume of superior quality microfluidic devices. The proposal seeks to develop a platform technology that produces the same manufacturing benefits as rapid prototyping and rapid manufacturing, though the resolution and surface finish will be optical grade on the micro scale. This may enable a variety of things including less expensive drug making, to faster disease diagnosis, to health benefits to the third world, to eliminating the backlog of rape-kits awaiting analysis. The end results - the lowering of medical expenses, faster diagnosis of disease, a boost in research, lowered pharmaceutical costs - are likely to be broadly beneficial. The technical innovation is a leap forward in the conceptual basis of Small Form Factor designs. The novelty of the idea opens and enables new research areas in engineering and chemical disciplines.

The project will address manufacture of very low cost (~1/10th the current market price) capillary electrophoresis (CE) chips by developing a platform technology for fast prototyping microfluidic chip layouts. The technology allows the formation of a three dimensional ?shell? of micron sized scale parts. The research will take a two-pronged approach: developing an improved understanding of interactions of the prototyping components and combining it with experimental development of a prototype ?T-shaped? CE chip. The theoretical aspect of the microfluidic molding, which has been demonstrated by a laboratory proof-of-concept experiment, will focus on understanding the feasible operating range and defining the performance limitations of the system. The experimental aspect will be dedicated to manipulation of the system to reveal the configuration required for the ?T-shaped? CE chip.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of the Phase I program was to develop an innovative platform technology for the rapid and inexpensive manufacture of capillary electrophoresis chips, with a view to expanding this technology to rapid prototyping and manufacture of any microfluidic chip. The technology proposed was to mold a polymer against a controllable mold cavity, which will ultimately be automated as a versatile and adaptable molding system.

Key in the Phase I project was the successful molding of the chips, primarily the successful molding of the fluidic channels, which can be seen in the attached figures. The project focused on refining and defining the method to fabricate microfluidic channels and wells, which form the basis of all microfluidic chips. The innovation, a novel method of manufacturing micro sized parts in three-dimensions all at once (i.e. no layering and no bonding) represents an entirely new field of research. The impacts are multiple—not merely an extension of solid freeform fabrication (SFF) techniques, but a leap forward in the conceptual basis of SFF. Additionally the idea opens and enables wide research areas in engineering, chemical, and materials disciplines.

The Phase I project showed a highly flexible process that can be adapted to a wide variety of channel styles and well styles quickly. The system can create a fully enclosed or open chip and no bonding is required. Specifications on tolerances, surface roughness meet or approach those found in specifications for existing CE chips and channels even using our coarse and manual fabrication process as it exists in Phase I. These numbers are expected to further improve with the introduction of automation and control.

In Phase I, microfluidic chips were produced with single channels, cross channels, “t” style channels, sinusoidal channels, and a variety of wells for fluid inputs and outputs. Channels were manufactured in the controllable range of 15-250 μm. The outer dimensions of the resulting prototype chips were found to be controllable such that thin film chips (<250 microns) could be fabricated and thick chips of the standardized size (75mm x 25.5mm x 1.5mm) could also be fabricated. This range of chip thicknesses creates opportunities for inexpensive standard sizes but also for new, more flexible (compliant) designs. The resulting prototype microfluidic chips have successfully demonstrated fluid flow through inlet wells, into the channels and exiting through the outlet channels. Form errors on channel width dimensions show a resolution (smallest channel width fabricated), accuracy (standard deviation of channel width from one chip to another) and repeatability (standard deviation of one channel width along the length) of 15µm, ±0.89µm, and ±0.25µm respectively. The average surface roughness of the channel bottom was found to be <10 nm RMS.  Control of channel cross-sectional dimensions and shape were demonstrated using a combination of finite element modeling and experimentation. Phase I used a manual method for the manufacture of the chip, which took 28.5 minutes for the process from start to finish; with automated controls, this should reduce the process time to 36 seconds. The SBIR Phase I showed that the HBN method has the advantages of the on-demand manufacture of 3-D printing and the scalability of injection molding to mass production.

The use for these microfluidic chips caters to the increasing societal need for low cost, disposable chips for portable diagnostic devices in the medical, environmental and biotechnical world. Lab-on-a-chip (LOC) technology is a key component to these systems, and the development of a versatile manufacturing platform will lead to devices ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The primary objective of the Phase I program was to develop an innovative platform technology for the rapid and inexpensive manufacture of capillary electrophoresis chips, with a view to expanding this technology to rapid prototyping and manufacture of any microfluidic chip. The technology proposed was to mold a polymer against a controllable mold cavity, which will ultimately be automated as a versatile and adaptable molding system. Key in the Phase I project was the successful molding of the chips, primarily the successful molding of the fluidic channels, which can be seen in the attached figures. The project focused on refining and defining the method to fabricate microfluidic channels and wells, which form the basis of all microfluidic chips. The innovation, a novel method of manufacturing micro sized parts in three-dimensions all at once (i.e. no layering and no bonding) represents an entirely new field of research. The impacts are multiple—not merely an extension of solid freeform fabrication (SFF) techniques, but a leap forward in the conceptual basis of SFF. Additionally the idea opens and enables wide research areas in engineering, chemical, and materials disciplines. The Phase I project showed a highly flexible process that can be adapted to a wide variety of channel styles and well styles quickly. The system can create a fully enclosed or open chip and no bonding is required. Specifications on tolerances, surface roughness meet or approach those found in specifications for existing CE chips and channels even using our coarse and manual fabrication process as it exists in Phase I. These numbers are expected to further improve with the introduction of automation and control. In Phase I, microfluidic chips were produced with single channels, cross channels, "t" style channels, sinusoidal channels, and a variety of wells for fluid inputs and outputs. Channels were manufactured in the controllable range of 15-250 μm. The outer dimensions of the resulting prototype chips were found to be controllable such that thin film chips (<250 microns) could be fabricated and thick chips of the standardized size (75mm x 25.5mm x 1.5mm) could also be fabricated. This range of chip thicknesses creates opportunities for inexpensive standard sizes but also for new, more flexible (compliant) designs. The resulting prototype microfluidic chips have successfully demonstrated fluid flow through inlet wells, into the channels and exiting through the outlet channels. Form errors on channel width dimensions show a resolution (smallest channel width fabricated), accuracy (standard deviation of channel width from one chip to another) and repeatability (standard deviation of one channel width along the length) of 15µm, ±0.89µm, and ±0.25µm respectively. The average surface roughness of the channel bottom was found to be <10 nm RMS. Control of channel cross-sectional dimensions and shape were demonstrated using a combination of finite element modeling and experimentation. Phase I used a manual method for the manufacture of the chip, which took 28.5 minutes for the process from start to finish; with automated controls, this should reduce the process time to 36 seconds. The SBIR Phase I showed that the HBN method has the advantages of the on-demand manufacture of 3-D printing and the scalability of injection molding to mass production. The use for these microfluidic chips caters to the increasing societal need for low cost, disposable chips for portable diagnostic devices in the medical, environmental and biotechnical world. Lab-on-a-chip (LOC) technology is a key component to these systems, and the development of a versatile manufacturing platform will lead to devices that aid in giving fast and needed feedback to users outside of a laboratory setting.
